Award.AwardTitle: RET SITE: Milwaukee Regional Energy Education Initiative

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award for a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site Program at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) entitled, RET SITE: Milwaukee Regional Energy Education Initiative (MREEI), under the direction of Dr. David C. Yu. The rationale for the MREEI RET site is to train secondary teachers through fundamental energy-related research and translational activities that are tied to industry, and then leverage curricular approaches that allow them to directly transition this knowledge into highly inspirational STEM experiences for their students.

The three engineering colleges in Milwaukee-the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Marquette University, and the Milwaukee School of Engineering-are partnering with regional industry and the Milwaukee Public School (MPS) system, to develop a collaborative RET Site focusing on the theme of energy. MREEI will annually engage 10 local mathematics and science high school teachers for six summer weeks in hands-on, cutting edge engineering research projects in energy-related fields. Energy was specifically chosen for the theme because it is a current topic of direct interest to students and teachers, it can be easily embedded into the high school science curriculum, and it is a core area of research for the three participating engineering schools and regional industry. Potential research topics for the RET participants include renewable and alternative energy, nano-scale sensor development, advanced materials, wind turbine blade design, and carbon capture and sequestration. As part of their scientific research projects, the teachers will be linked with real-world applications through collaborations with industry partners.

MREEI will impact 30 teachers and 4500 students from high-need urban public high schools in the city of Milwaukee. More importantly, this proposal and its activities directly align with Milwaukee Public School systems new vision for science and mathematics and its Comprehensive Math and Science Plan (CMSP) which will be implemented during the 2011 academic year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was for teacher-participants to transfer their research experience in the areas of energy into curriculum that includes engineering concepts for their students. Our RET Site recruited and trained 24 teachers in three cohorts (8 teachers in 2012, 2 returning mentor teachers and 8 new teachers in 2013, and 2 returning mentor teachers and 8 new teachers in 2014). Demographics of teachers: 11 female (45.8%) and 13 male (54.2%), 14 science (58.3%) and 10 math (41.7%) teachers. 19 of 24 teachers (79%) were from the Milwaukee Public School District. At the last estimated count, the RET teachers implemented curriculum impacted 1,700 students. RET has successfully recruited participants that meet the target audience expectations for the project. Most participants are teachers in urban high schools teaching science or math courses, which is aligned with the content knowledge development. Almost all teachers presented at the Annual Wisconsin Mathematics Council- and Wisconsin Society of State Teachers Conferences and one teacher published a peer reviewed journal article.

One of the project goals was to increase student interest in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) careers and improved science content knowledge and pedagogy keyed to the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Multiple measures related to these goals had been established. Key among these is the Diagnostic Science Assessments for Middle School Teachers (DTAMS), which were used to evaluate participant?content knowledge; the Surveys of Enacted Curriculum (SEC) that?was designed to evaluate adoption of inquiry based teaching?practices; and the student surveys used to assess student attitudes?towards and interest in STEM careers. The evaluation also?incorporated classroom observations of a sample of participating?teachers using the O-TOP protocol. Observations evaluated the?extent to which teacher practice is aligned with activities that may improve student interest as a result of participation in the institute. The following conclusions are offered based on the collected data:

1. There is room for improvement in participant content knowledge. The DTAMS results show that most participants score about 40-50 percent on these assessments. While participants have a strong foundation of college coursework, this has likely been lost through everyday teaching and the lack of alignment between coursework and mandated curriculum. In addition, some of the math teachers have little background in Physical Science; however, they show significant improvement in knowledge after their research experience in the university engineering laboratories.

2. There is weak to moderate alignment between science standards and the actual curriculum being taught by participants as shown by the Surveys of Enacted Curriculum. Again, this is likely due to the mandated curriculum and its lack of alignment with accepted standards.

Overall, the evaluation results suggest that the recruited participants have benefited greatly from the RET program. In addition, the students of RET participants benefited through more constructivist methods in the classroom.  The evaluation data did not show that students’ attitudes toward STEM improved statistically significantly in the first year of the program; however, the students’ ratings of attitude toward science and math had improved after the lessons were implemented. In addition, in our final year of assessment (Cohort #3) our team was able to more accurately analyze student reported career interest data.
